text: Pope Pius XI (; , 31 May 1857â€“10 February 1939), born Achille Ratti, was an Italian priest of the Roman Catholic Church and the 260th Pope from 1922 to 1939. "List of Popes," Catholic Encyclopedia (2009); retrieved 2011-11-02. ==Priest== Ratti was ordained as a priest in 1875. "Pope Pius XI", Embryo Project (2010); retrieved 2011-11-02. Father Ratti was a professor at the Padua Seminary from 1882 to 1888. He worked at Ambrosian Library of Milan from 1888 to 1911; and at the Vatican Library from 1911-1914. ==Bishop== In 1919, Pope Benedict XV made Ratti a Bishop of Lepanto. "Pontiff Spent His Life in Religion From His Boyhood Years," New York Times. February 10, 1939; retrieved 2011-11-9. In 1921, Benedict named him Archbishop of Milan. ==Cardinal== In 1921, Ratti was made a cardinal. Pius XI, a Diplomat and a Deep Student," New York Times. February 7, 1922; retrieved 2011-11-9. ==Pope== Cardinal Ratti was elected pope on February 6, 1922; and he chose the name Pope Pius XI. Some of his decisions were controversial. He made 18 concordats (treaties) with foreign governments. They included the Lateran Concordat with Italy in 1929; and the Reichskoncordat with Germany in 1933.Flinn, Frank K. et al. (2007).
